Official university functions
have come to a complete
standstill as a result of last
night's revolt.
In fact, communications
between the "administration-in-exile" and the outside
world have been completely
cut.
One of SDS's first moves
had been to "liberate" the
University switchboard. All
incoming calls to the
University are being
monitored by SDS
functionaries.
The Office of Institutional
Public Relations and its
work has come to a
complete standstill. Director
James Butler, trapped in his
office during the seizure of
Sh river Hall, was seen
pacing back and forth
moaning, "What'll I tell the
alumni? What'll I tell the
parents."
Butler had earlier
attempted to get a release
to the local and national
press stating that last night's
frenetic activity was "merely

Special to the News-Letter

By BRUCE DRAKE
War Correspondent

Hopkins Students for a Democratic Society
(S DS), with the aid of unidentified outside
.forces, staged a successful armed coup last night.
At last report, 90 % of the Homewood campus
is under SDS occupation.
SDS forces opened a four-front attack at
approximately 5 p.m. yesterday evening. Guerilla
bands staged lightning attacks on Shriver Hall
and a separate unit occupied Levering. A larger
force siezed the freshmen dormitories at
approximately 7 p.m., and the Eisenhower
Library fell by midnight.

quickly, as over 80% of
the campus was liberated

The numbers of, students

according to Shriver,
"exactly what we expected."
Throughout the late evening,
the students swarmed over
the campus, seizing the
upperclass dorms, toolshed,
and other strategic positions.
Commented one student,
raising the red flag of

upperclass dorms, "The
insurrection must succeed,
because it is idealogically

reason for the widespread
student support was voiced

"I joined because it is
about time that some sort
of excitement happened on
this campus."

noted that of 27 committees in
the U.S.. Office of Education
during the vacation period, not
one had young people represented
on it.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE,DEC. 6, 1968

NEWS-LETTER

Dominion Prosperity Lauded

News Briefs
SAIS Gets Donner Grant
Ceremonies were held at SAIS last month when Dr.
Lincoln Gordon and Dean Francis 0. Wilcox announced
that a five-year grant of $ 1,000,000 has been made to
the school by the William H. Donner Foundati
the Donner Canadian Foundation for the establish on and
ment of
a Center of Canadian Foundation for
the establishment
of a Center of Canadian Studies. This Center will be
an important part of the School's graduate program.
The Center's programs will emphasize the study of
Canadian history, culture, government, economics, and
society. Its ultimate objective is to promote better
relations between the two countries and to enhance
Canada's position in world affairs.
Students from Canada and the U.S. will be enrolled
next fall.

Biafran War Vigil Is Today
A nine-hour vigil to express public concern over the
plight of the victims of the Biafran War will be held
today at Hopkins Plaza, Charles and
Lombard Streets.
Six folk groups will participate in the
demonstration,which will be highlighted by a candlelight
ceremony. In addition, various clergymen will be present
to speak, as well as Ted Jackson of
the American
Friends Service Committee. The vigil will begin at 3 in
the afternoon and end at midnight.
The public is invited to come and hold a candle
for
Biafra.

Homewood To Spruce-Up
A Christmas-time "spruce-up" of the greater Homewood
area will begin tomorrow with a "clean-up day." Home
holiday decorations will be encouraged and a
neighborhood Christmas tree will be trimmed.
JHU students will assist the Remington Improvement
Association, the Baltimore City Sanitation Division, and
the Greater Homewood Community Project in the
c
spruce-up" campaign. Among other things, students will
man brooms and distribute posters.
The Greater Homewood Community Project provides a
mobilization of community, institutional, and individual
resources to revitalize an approximately one square mile
around the JHU Homewood campus.

Violence Report Suppressed
The Government Printing Office refused to publish the
Walker report on Violence at the Chicago convention
because the author refused to delete frequent obscenities
hi the document.
GPO insisted on replacing the obscenities with dash
lines, but Walker would not permit this sub3titution. He
said that the obscenities were used by police and
demonstrators at the convention and that their removal
Would "destroy the important tone of the dncument."
Although the government refused to print the report
for public distribution. Bantam Books, Inc. has agreed to
print at least 250,000 copies which should be on the
newsstands by today.

c Bonn Brothel Bows

Center" on December 1 as Bonn, Germany's first legal
house of prostitution opened for business.
Prostitutes from Bonn, Frankfort, - Dusseldorf, and Paris
Will occupy the building, erected in spite of strong
Protests from its neighbors. Local courts feel the
enterprise will help bring the oldest pi-ofession under
Control.
The house consists of two buildings
courtyard. Each woman will pay $150 a and an inner
month to rent
a one-room apartment.

attractiveness of city life."
Although 30-40% of
adults remain illiterate, Latin
Americans are beginning to
"take the universal education
concept seriously."
Political development
reflects the emergence of a
large and influential middle
class. There is a spreading
interest in the workings of
government, and even the
military, long a major
political force in Latin
American, is losing its role
. as the protector of
oligarchic interests and has
begun to "reflect the new

'nationalism of the urban
, middle class."
Dr. Gordon attempted to
'refute the "myth of the
revolutionary panacea," which
implies that "all of Latin
America requires a violent
revolution before any
meaningful progress can
occur." Gordon states that
"violent revolution is neither
needed, nor humane, nor
effective." "Nowhere in
Latin America is there a
frozen society" such as
prevailed in Mexico before
its revolution. Gordon hopes
to see "rapid change...with-

out a bloodbath."
Gordon noted that the chief
interest of the United States
"lies in aiding Latin
America develop its potential
Turning towards the field

to become a world power

Latin America, with United

New Profs Evaluate JHU
Last week three new*
Hopkins professors, in three
separate interviews, gave their
views concerning Hopkins
students.
Dr. Peter Rossi, Chairman
of the Social Relations
Department, has also taught
at Harvard, Columbia and
Chicago. Dr. Rossi said that
Hopkins students are as
bright as the students at
the other schools at which
he has taught but that
Hopkins men are not as
verbally aggressive. He
stressed that it is harder to
get Hopkins students to
participate in class. When
Rossi got here, he was
surprised at the number of
people who studied for
.grades but he said that this
is understandable because of
the high percentage of
students at JHU planning to
go to graduate schools
which are preoccupied with
grades.
Dr. Robert Hogan,
psychology professor at
Hopkins, has previously
taught at Berkeley. Dr.
Hogan pointed out that
Hopkins students have it
"soft" compared to Berkeley
students. Hogan said that at
Berkeley, the professors were
more remote and that
graduate students there were
treated much worse than
undergraduates at Hopkins.
Dr. Hogan believes that
although the average Hopkins
student is more capable
than the average Berkeley
student, the Hopkins student
is also more preoccupied
with grades than the
acquisition of knowledge or

sinsight. Dr. Hogan cited the
provincial attitude of many
Hopkins students.
I Dr. Stephen Stephens of
the political science
department at Hopkins said
that there is at least a
,minority of intellectually
'interesting students at JHU.
IHe said that the political
.science students at Yale
(where Stephens also taught)
'were dull, homogeneous, and
imore interested in "pre-law"

than political science.
Dr. Stephens feels that
the pre-law students pose a
problem for the political
science department at
Hopkins as well as most
other schools. The reason
for this is that the pre-law
students seem more
interested in obtaining an
entree into the establishment
than actually mastering the
nuances of political science.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE,DEC. 6, 1968

NEWS-LETTER

PAGE 8

Strider Predicts Draft May Hurt llomewood'Pepartments
Robert L. Strider,
Associate Dean of Arts and
Sciences, has predicted
that up to 5% of -Hopkin's
full-time graduate students
may fail to complete this
school year because of
increased draft calls.
A recently completed
survey at Hopkins shows
that 63 of the 1,151
full-time graduate students in
the arts and sciences
program could be called by
the draft between now and
next June. Strider, who
compiled the study,

maintained that as of this
time nothing definite had
been decided, since the
impact of selective service
would not be fully
determinable until at least
the end of the first
semester.
Lt. Gen. Lewis Hershey,

The Hullaballoo
Last year's Hullaballoo, 1967, was an interesting and
partially successful attempt to experiment with a
yearbook as an art form--to capture the emotions of a
year, to capture a fleeting period called "college".
This year's product, on a first impression, seems to
be a satire on last year's edition. The superstars of
1967 are back—another batch of photographs of Hopkins'
favorite model Joel Ziskin; and, in addition, the same
girl who starred in a four page spread—standing in a
debris lot with boy-friend, playing hide-and-seek with
boy-friend, and mouthing it with boy-friend. Through
hard work, we suppose, she worked her way up to a
full page solo appearance in 1968. Perhaps next year,
we will be treated to an in-depth microscopic study of
the cellular structure of this dynamic duo.
The ingenuity of 1968's staff does not end here,
however. We are also treated to an entire book of Elia
Katz, a figure well-known to "with it" Hopkins literati.
Hopkins literati will also discover that the Katz booklet
is the twentieth variation on his "Buster" stories which
he has been peddling around Baltimore since his arrival.
At this point, speaking of Katz, we should mention
the season for producing a soft cover yearbook. For
financial reasons, the soft-covered edition was necessary in
order to accommodate the Katz edition.
In addition to these disturbing complaints, the
selection of photographs were poor, the group shots
(especially of sports teams) were wooden and sloppy,
and the book's composition itself was medicore. The use
of photo offset for printing was also a poor decision,
as one might note from scattered crooked lines of
copy.
Gary Nothstein, chairman of SAC which controls funds
for student activities, has frozen the Hullaballoo 's money.
This is a cause for concern.
We can understand what the Hullaballoo staff has
been trying to do with the yearbook in recent years
as evidenced by the 1967 edition. We also can
understand the actions of SAC in freezing Hullaballoo
funds. The current yearbook not only fails as "art",
but it has also failed to provide the students with an
acceptable product. Undoubtedly, the Hullaballoo has
disappointed those graduated seniors who wished to have
a record of their years at Hopkins.
However, we do hope that those who are now
investigating the status of the yearbook will understand
the necessity for ensuring that the Hullaballoo as a
publication, will continue to operate with editorial
independence in the future. Heavy-handed actions which
would convert the Hullaballoo to a high school level
publication would be regrettable.
It is imperative that the present staff of the
Hullaballoo and the committee now evaluating its
performance reach an agreement which will preserve the
editorial integrity of the yearbook and yet guarantee a
more responsible operation in relation to the students
they serve.
However, two facts should be kept in mind when
judging the Hullaballoo. First, student involvement in the
actual production of the book has been minimal in past
years. The yearbook is virtually put together by a
handful of students. Second, most of the work is done
during summer vacation when few students are willing or,
able to spend the time working on the book.
The latter problem can be remedied by the
Hullaballoo staff, itself, by juggling their deadline dates.
The former, however, depends completely on whether
Hopkins undergraduates really give a damn whether they
have a yearbook or not.

Dr. Gordon's Speech
Dr. Gordon's speech on the opening day of the
Eisenhower Symposium contained a striking touch of
irony. The Baltimore Sun applauded Dr. Gordon for,
"counseling against United States' intervention in Latin
American political affairs."
It was Dr. Gordon, as Ambassador to Brazil, who, a
scant three weeks after the military ouster of Joao
Goulart, announced his support of the forces who
overthrew a democratically elected president.
It was Dr. Gordon, in 1966, who, as Assistant
Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, told Alliance for
Progress members that the U.S. was putting "buy
American" strings on its aid. Why? According to Dr.
Gordon, the reason for such strings was to help rectify
balan,:e1 of payments deficits incurred by the "struggle
for freedom in Vietnam." Thus, reasoned Dr. Gordon,
the practice of "tied aid" was necessary.

IFilthy Corner Theatre I
By BILL MARGRABE
Although most people familiar
with the Corner Theater
Experimental Theater Club since
its inception over nine months
ago would agree that it is quite
pregnant with new ideas, there
has been an obvious failure of the
normally arty and compassionate
people of Baltimore to come to
her aid during this crucial time;
those derelict include the Hopkins
community. Les Irons, director,
has been especially concerned
with the number of people who
have joined, attended one
production, praised the
performance, then disappeared
from the experimental theater's
scene. "Attendance is our life
blood," he says.
CT'ETC, which opened in
February of 1968, is exactly what
its full name implies. The Corner
Theater bit reminds us that it is in
a sense a reincarnation of Corner
Theater Projects, which was a
1967 effort at giving Baltimore a
taste of the good thing NYC had
in Cafe' La Mama, founded there
by Ellen Stewart. Plays produced
by Corner Theater Projects
include The Burial by C. Richard
Gillespie, head of the drama
department at Towson State, and
John Osborne's Look Back in
Anger. It is a cafe' because drinks
(coffee, tea, and cocoa) are
available on the house, and
because conversation is easy to
come by before, between, and
after the plays.
Up Tight
One quote might be enough to
convince you that this is
experimental theater. According
to the Baltimore Sun a college girl
remarked that it was strange "to
have a man and woman making

love on top of her" during one of,
the plays. Of note is the apparent
demolition of the cliche' "three's
a crowd" during that show; the
girl said iit was "one of the most
exciting things that ever happened
to me." Also consonant with the.
"experimental" claim are the
Club's twin goals of offering
experimental drama to the public
and encouraging local playwrights
by producing their plays, as
production of The Burial
indicates.
.
Why a club? Because at this
time it is impractical to maintain
official "theater" status, which
would involve following the union
wage scale and fringe benefit
dictates, a theater tax, moving the
theater because of zoning lawas
from its current rent-free location
across from a hospital in the
800-block of North Howard
Street, and possible complications
resulting from objections to
sexual and scatalogical jargon.
The Club favors "using them so
freely that they'll cease to stand
out," says the Sun.
No doubt you are anxious to
hear more about CT'ETC, and
how you may become a part of
the groovy scene. CTETC is at
853 North Howard Street; its
shows run two weeks at a time
from Thursday night through
Monday night, starting always at
9 p.m. Membership for life is-five
dollars. Now playing are, The
abilsess of ladj
, Bright and At
Last We Are Alone Together, the
latter a "camp comedy" and the
fornier a "surrealistic" play from
the theatre of homosexuality.
Very Gay Blade
"Lady Bright" is a fat male
homo who goes mad before your
very eyes, unfolding the causes in

the process. "She" starts the play
trying to find somebody to share
the evening with, but nobody
seems to be around. They are all
out playing with someone else
and the "Lady" is forgotten. The
only voices she can depend on
answering "her" are dial-a-prayer,
the voices within her mind, and
the commercial ones: the airlines,
the time, weather, etc.
The Lady returns to the past,
letting the signatures of her many
callers, now preserved on her wall,
crayon symbols of the good old
days, guide her thoughts. There
was Adam, whom she had always
wanted, but never got, and
Michael Delaney, who convinced
her that the Irish could be "very
good," too. But those days were
gone. Lady Bright is old, worn
out, unwanted, alone, lonely, and
does not see any escape from this
debilitating state.
One may conclude from this
something about homosexuality:
Lady Bright was simply a fag who
was not getting her required
amount of social-sexual
relationships, Hence the crackup.
More generally the play's theme is
human loneliness; and, although
the theme is tired, the
presentation impresses one with
its novelty. Indeed, many people
may find it shocking.
There is an enthusiastic group
of Club members who feel that
experimental theater, now
overdue for acceptance should
not disappear. Indeed, it would be
a miscarriage of divine justice if
this attempt to bring a little bit of
life to Baltimore were abortive.
So, by all means see "Lady
Bright" and start an affair that
could be of immense benefit to
you and to Baltimore.

Who The Hell Is William Sulzer?
By ED MENDELSOHN
Standard studies of the
Progressive period indicate that
the officeholders of the time held
unusually high ideals. Richard
Hofstadter, for instance, states
that leadership was divided among
Wilson, Roosevelt, Bryan and
LaFollette, One may disagree
with these men, but they were
unquestionably ethical and
sincerely devoted to democratic
theory. However, they represent
only the apogee of Progressive
leadership. That there was a
perigee may be demonstrated by
the career of William Sulzer.
Sulzer was born in 1863 to
immigrant parents; as he put it,
The plain people know me." At
the age of 26 he was elected to
the New York State Assembly,
Where he became Democratic
leader in three years and advanced
to Speaker after the Democrats
won control in 1892. In 1894 he
won a previously Republican
House seat in New York City.
This could not be attributed to a
Democratic tide, since Sulzer's
party had 19 New York House
seats entering 1894 and could
only elect five. Sulzer was
continuously elected through
1910, acquiring more seniority
than any other Northern
Democractic Representative, and
when the Democrats finally won
control of Congress in 1910
Sulzer became Chairman of the
pretigious Foreign Affairs
Committee.
Weighty Career
Sulzer's legislative career is
notable for the sheer volume of
his proposed legislation, a little of
Which actually passed. Sometimes
he seemed to be merely catering
to the ethnic groups in his
district, as when he proposed to
make Columbus Day a national
holiday, to erect statues in
Washington to Generals de Kalb
and von Steuben, and to adopt a
resolution deploring Russian
treatment of Jews. Occasionally
he was astonishingly prescient, as
when he proposed a Cabinet-level
Department of Transportation, a
project which was consummated
about half a century later.
In 1912, Sulzer received what
he had long angled for, the
Democratic nomination for

Heart Transplant Performed at Hopkins Hospital
By SANDRA R. HAMMER
A team of surgical
Personnel led by Dr.
Vincent Gott and Dr.
Harvey Bender performed the
first heart transplant at the
Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions on November 25,
1968.
Mr. Sydney Seidenberg, a
56 year old real estate
dealer from Baltimore,
received the heart of a 26
Year old victim of
irreversible brain damage, Mr.
Wilson Lieske of Havre de
Grace, Md.
Mr. Seidenberg has
experienced a progressive and
satisfactory recovery from
the operation. His vital signs
have remained within normal
limits, and he is reported
to be doing very well.
Standard Technique
The operation was
performed using the standard
open-heart technique
developed at Hopkins. Dr.
Bender removed the
recipient's heart while Mr.
Seidenberg was being
maintained on the
cardio-pulmonary by-pass
apparatus, and Dr. Gott
removed the donor's heart.
Both physicians then
installed the new heart into
Mr. Seidenberg.
The entire surgical
procedure lasted six hours.
The major concern now
entails the prevention of
infection and rejection of
the new organ.
Having undertaken two
heart operations previous to
this admission, Mr.
Seidenberg understood that
his "only hope was to get
a new heart muscle." The
recipient came to JHH one
day prior to the operation
for evaluation of a
myocardial (heart muscle)
disorder. Upon examination,
his heart appeared to be
enlarged and functioning
poorly.
"Days or Weeks"
His life at the time of
surgery could be measured
only "in days or perhaps

The Dark Ages

It is entirely possible
That is how History will refer to our time...
When the smog hovering over our cities
The dark hunger haunting our tenements
The darker crime stalking our streets
Is remembered.
However History describes our era
We hope it will also
be remembered
As the time when a young girl's heart
Beat a moment of life into a dying man .
As the time when primitive peoples
Leaped across centuries of progress
To take their place at
The World conference table..
As the time when Man first struggled to
Close the gap between the
Social and technological sciences.
You don't start clean.
Your Century is partially written.
If your chapter is to carry the torch
That can blaze across the dark corners of our age
You face a job of heroic proportions.
We think you're up to it.
You are our life insurance.

By RICH HOLLANDER
Sports Editor
I wish that the varsity basketball schedule-maker would
consult the News-Letter before he does his thing. To
appreciate my predicament, realize that the varsity
opened against Lebanon Valley last night and this
preview was scratched out two days before that. It's
something like the theatre critic who is reviewing a
play he hasn't seen but everyone else has.
Nevertheless, the roster didn't change last night and
that's the source of the hoopsters' weakness and coach
Henry Ciccarone's challenge. Even for a team that grew
up in the vitamin generation they're too small.
Excepting Bill Pietrowski and Geoff Thomas, the squad
hovers a r ou n d six feet. The natural and essential
compensation is speed and defense. Plans call for
constant defensive pressure in the hope of causing
turnovers, and keeping opponents from second and third
shots. With the ball, you'll see an exciting display of
th6 classic "run and gun" offense.
"WHO'S WHO IN BASKETBALL"
Senior co-captain Hal Thorne is one of the four
returning lettermen. He'll quarterback both the offense
and defense, calling all the plays. Although only 5 ft.
6 in., he's deadly from short range. Brain Berke is the
other senior co-captain and will engineer the running
game. Needless to say, anyone who has grown up on
Brooklyn B. Ball, like Brian, knows the game. At 6 ft.
5 in., Geoff Thomas is the Jay's board strength.
Despite the rebounding responsibilities, Thomas will
average in double figures. If the chemistry department
can come up with an aggressive pill for Bill Pietrowski,
the 6 ft. 7 in. junior can make the Jay's big winners.
PRESENT OR FUTURE?
As coach Ciccarone puts it, "Depending how fast the
sophomores mature into the varsity system, the more
games we're going to win." Last year's leading frosh
scorer, Dave Rebovich, who averaged 14.4, will hold
down the third guard slot. Joes Loveland is a complete
ballplayer, yet he specializes in pilfering basketballs.
Count on Loveland in the clutch. Should the age of
being a senior reach Thorne, he'll be backed up by
Sam Katz. Combining with Rebovich at guard last year,
Sam was consistently in double figure range.
If you want to sound like an expert, tell your date
that the varsity is working off a 1-4 offense. When
they don't set up, you'll see the organized chaos of
free lance offense. Simply, it's characterized by the
guards on the inside acting like pivot men. The defense
is less predictable. Try cliches like "full court
man-to-man" or "full court zone-press". She'll never
know the difference.
STAR ATTRACTIONS
In the course of the seventeen game season, the
Jay's will face (unfortunately) many outstanding palyers
and teams. Foremost will be Hopkins' nemesis
Muhlenberg. The Mules have everyone back from last
year's tournament team. They're sporting center Bob
McClure, who marked for 305 points as a freshman
playing varsity last season. As usual PMC and Drexel
will be tough. The sleeper of the league will be
Washington College. After a year's absence, forward Bob
Koepke, will return to the hardwoods. He was the
leading scorer on the University of Maryland freshman
team a couple of years ago,

Two Teams Gain Glory
As Fall Season Ends
By RICH HOLLANDER
Champagne all around!
Take that literally and
figuratively. There's a fiesta
on December 16 to honor
the victorious football and
soccer teams. The Jay
gri dm e n repeated for the
second straight year a:
champs of the Middle
Atlantic Conference's
Northern Division. In the
same league the soccer team
finished third out of 17
schools—their best mark since
1953.
It's the exceptional college
team that can be big
winners in successive
campaigns. Generally coaches.
build for one championship
at a time. Alex Sotir is
an exceptional coach. Using
the nucleus from last year
he molded the sophomores
and brought to Homewood
a superlative 7-2-0 record.
SATURDAY HEROES
On the Saturday before
Thanksgiving, the Jays lashed
into hapless Western
Maryland 46 to 23. This
was the icing of the

traditional rivalry, which saw
both the soccer and
cross-country teams devastate
the Terrors.
From the opening
squeaker with Muhlenberg to
the wasting of Western
Maryland the Jays scored'
306 points to 185 for
their opponents. Statistics are
the mark of a winner.
Offensives are built
around backfields and the
'68 and '67 champs are
identical. Southpaw Jim
Feely ran the show as
quarterback. Hampered by a
shoulder injury much of the
season he didn't really get
started until the closing
weeks. Neverhteless, he threw
95 completions for 1425
yards and 18 touchdowns.
His most impressive
performance was against
Dickinson where he chalked
up 262 yards. Feely's
elusive scrambling and adroit
ballhandling has set an.
example for future
generations of Hopkins'
quarterbacks. Antoher injured
here was Paul Weiss. This
year, in his junior season,
Paul led the Jays in
rushing and scoring.

Smashing tackles at a 5.6
clip, he amassed 886 yards.
Especially tough around the
g o all ine, Weiss found the
end zone 14 times. Fullback
Mark Croft provided blocking
muscle and mostly to the
inside. Rarely downed on
solo tackles, Croft drilled
the goal line on 8
occasions. Wingback Joe
Cowan has received more
copy in this paper than
Lincoln Gordon. Cowan does
most of everything and a
little bit more. One of the
most electrifying players ever
to try on a Hopkins'
jersey, Joe caught 30 Feely
passes for 651 yards and 7
scores. Color Joe great and
give him 5 more
touchdowns on the ground.

SENIORS
With the championship
comes the tragic prospect of
losing 12 seniors. Co-captains
Willie Scroggs and Don
Yablonowitz did outstanding
jobs as leaders and are
superlative athletes. Aside
from Croft, Feely and
Cowan the Western Maryland
game signalled the careers'
end for Larry Daniels, Whit
Holden, Dave Komocki, Bill
Nersesian, Gay Pasternak,
John Peck and Phil
Schro del. These men can
credit themselves with two
championships, an
achievement few varsity
college players can boast.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, DEC. 6, 1968

NEWS-LETTER

SA Offers Draft Program and Tom Jones
There will be three
showings on Saturday,
December 7th, at 4, 7:30
and 10 pm. and a final
showing on Sunday at 4
pm. All the showings will
be in the Great Hall of
Levering. Admission is $1.25
for the common people and
$.75 for card-carrying SA
members.

As soon as the draft
counseling program ends, the
SA will begin the first of
four showings of the
award -winning film, Tom
Jones. The movie is directed
by Tony Richardson and
features Albert Finney,
Susannah York and Joan
Greenwood.

The Student Association'
will keep Levering Hall's.
facilities in almost continual
use this weekend with a
special program on draft
counseling and two social
events.
The draft counselor
training program, sponsored'
by Dr. Wickwire, will begin;
at 9:30 am. this Saturday
morning, December 7th, and
run until 3:30 pm. The
speaker for the day will be
Mr. Arlo Tatum, Director of
the Central Committee for
Conscientious Objectors.
Participants in thei
program will have an
opportunity to examine the
Selective Service regulations
in depth in terms of their
effect on both graduate and
undergraduate students.
Anyone who wishes to
attend the session should
come to the SA office
today or call HO 7-3300,
ext. 624 or 403.

Mixed Media Hits Levering
Dr. Wickwire will take
another step into the
unknown with his innovative
Sunday Service program this
Sunday, December 8th.
Entitled "A Service in
Drama, Mime and Media"
this Sunday's program will
feature a mixed mcdia
production of Paul Claudel's
drame, Tobias and Sara. Dr.
Richard Gillespie will direct
the Glen Players of Towson
State College in the
presentation which will begin
at 11 am.

Sunday evening, Dr.
Wickwire will present Dr.
Leslie Dewart, a controversial
Roman Catholic theologian,
author and Lecturer from
St. Michael's College and
the University of Toronto.
He will speak at 8 pm. in
Levering's Great Hall on the
topic "A De-Hellenized God
for the 20th Century." On
Monday afternoon, at 2
pm., he will speak on
"Contemporary Atheism and
Christian Theism."
Dr. Dewart was born in
Spain and raised in Cuba
before he went to study in
Canada. He has taught at
the U. of Detroit as well
as at several Canadian
schools.

Seniors and
Graduate Students

SC Votes Bail
Money Refund
To Protestors
In the past two weeks,
the Student Council has
made two important
decisions with regard to
student rights.
The first action was
taken on November 25th
when the Council voted to
re fund bail to those
students who were arrested
in the demonstrations in
Washington, D.C., on
Election Day. The funds
were approved for all those
who were charged with
''demonstrating without a
permit."
In an equally important
decision the Council's request
for limited representation on
the Academic Council was
granted
As a result of the
Academic Council's approval
of student representation, the
SC established a committee
on student relations. It will
serve as a subcommittee of
the Academic Council and
will have two regular
members, two undergraduates,
two graduates and two
faculty members. (See article
on Page 5.)

Library fell by midnight.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE,DEC. 6, 1968

NEWS-LETTER

Dominion Prosperity Lauded

News Briefs
SAIS Gets Donner Grant
Ceremonies were held at SAIS last month when Dr.
Lincoln Gordon and Dean Francis 0. Wilcox announced
that a five-year grant of $ 1,000,000 has been made to
the school by the William H. Donner Foundati
the Donner Canadian Foundation for the establish on and
ment of
a Center of Canadian Foundation for
the establishment
of a Center of Canadian Studies. This Center will be
an important part of the School's graduate program.
The Center's programs will emphasize the study of
Canadian history, culture, government, economics, and
society. Its ultimate objective is to promote better
relations between the two countries and to enhance
Canada's position in world affairs.
Students from Canada and the U.S. will be enrolled
next fall.

Biafran War Vigil Is Today
A nine-hour vigil to express public concern over the
plight of the victims of the Biafran War will be held
today at Hopkins Plaza, Charles and
Lombard Streets.
Six folk groups will participate in the
demonstration,which will be highlighted by a candlelight
ceremony. In addition, various clergymen will be present
to speak, as well as Ted Jackson of
the American
Friends Service Committee. The vigil will begin at 3 in
the afternoon and end at midnight.
The public is invited to come and hold a candle
for
Biafra.

Homewood To Spruce-Up
A Christmas-time "spruce-up" of the greater Homewood
area will begin tomorrow with a "clean-up day." Home
holiday decorations will be encouraged and a
neighborhood Christmas tree will be trimmed.
JHU students will assist the Remington Improvement
Association, the Baltimore City Sanitation Division, and
the Greater Homewood Community Project in the
c
spruce-up" campaign. Among other things, students will
man brooms and distribute posters.
The Greater Homewood Community Project provides a
mobilization of community, institutional, and individual
resources to revitalize an approximately one square mile
around the JHU Homewood campus.

Violence Report Suppressed
The Government Printing Office refused to publish the
Walker report on Violence at the Chicago convention
because the author refused to delete frequent obscenities
hi the document.
GPO insisted on replacing the obscenities with dash
lines, but Walker would not permit this sub3titution. He
said that the obscenities were used by police and
demonstrators at the convention and that their removal
Would "destroy the important tone of the dncument."
Although the government refused to print the report
for public distribution. Bantam Books, Inc. has agreed to
print at least 250,000 copies which should be on the
newsstands by today.

c Bonn Brothel Bows

Center" on December 1 as Bonn, Germany's first legal
house of prostitution opened for business.
Prostitutes from Bonn, Frankfort, - Dusseldorf, and Paris

Protests from its neighbors. Local courts feel the
enterprise will help bring the oldest pi-ofession under
Control.
The house consists of two buildings
courtyard. Each woman will pay $150 a and an inner
month to rent
a one-room apartment.

New Profs Evaluate JHU
Last week three new*
Hopkins professors, in three
separate interviews, gave their
views concerning Hopkins
students.
Dr. Peter Rossi, Chairman
of the Social Relations
Department, has also taught
at Harvard, Columbia and
Chicago. Dr. Rossi said that
Hopkins students are as
bright as the students at
the other schools at which
he has taught but that
Hopkins men are not as
verbally aggressive. He
stressed that it is harder to
get Hopkins students to
participate in class. When
Rossi got here, he was
surprised at the number of
people who studied for
.grades but he said that this
is understandable because of
the high percentage of
students at JHU planning to
go to graduate schools
which are preoccupied with
grades.
Dr. Robert Hogan,
psychology professor at
Hopkins, has previously
taught at Berkeley. Dr.
Hogan pointed out that
Hopkins students have it
"soft" compared to Berkeley
students. Hogan said that at
Berkeley, the professors were
more remote and that
graduate students there were
treated much worse than
undergraduates at Hopkins.
Dr. Hogan believes that
although the average Hopkins
student is more capable
than the average Berkeley
student, the Hopkins student
is also more preoccupied
with grades than the
acquisition of knowledge or

sinsight. Dr. Hogan cited the
provincial attitude of many
Hopkins students.
I Dr. Stephen Stephens of
the political science
department at Hopkins said
that there is at least a
,minority of intellectually
'interesting students at JHU.
IHe said that the political
.science students at Yale
(where Stephens also taught)
'were dull, homogeneous, and
imore interested in "pre-law"

than political science.
Dr. Stephens feels that
the pre-law students pose a
problem for the political
science department at
Hopkins as well as most
other schools. The reason
for this is that the pre-law
students seem more
interested in obtaining an
entree into the establishment
than actually mastering the
nuances of political science.

Strider Predicts Draft May Hurt llomewood'Pepartments
Robert L. Strider,
Associate Dean of Arts and
Sciences, has predicted
that up to 5% of -Hopkin's
full-time graduate students
may fail to complete this
school year because of
increased draft calls.
A recently completed
survey at Hopkins shows
that 63 of the 1,151
full-time graduate students in
the arts and sciences
program could be called by
the draft between now and
next June. Strider, who
compiled the study,

maintained that as of this
time nothing definite had
been decided, since the
impact of selective service
would not be fully
determinable until at least
the end of the first
semester.
Lt. Gen. Lewis Hershey,
director of Selective Service,
has recommended that local
draft boards let service-bound
graduate students finish the
current semester. However,
some draft boards are not
following the Hershey
recommendation and are

drafting students in
mid-semester.
"It is too early to tell .
just how bad the situation
will be," said Strider, "but
the top priority of the
university must be to
supply teaching assistants to
the undergraduate body." In
order to fill this priority,
he envisions the possible•
hiring of part-time substitute
teachers to fill the vacancies
of drafted graduate students.

The Hullaballoo
Last year's Hullaballoo, 1967, was an interesting and
partially successful attempt to experiment with a
yearbook as an art form--to capture the emotions of a
year, to capture a fleeting period called "college".
This year's product, on a first impression, seems to
be a satire on last year's edition. The superstars of
1967 are back—another batch of photographs of Hopkins'
favorite model Joel Ziskin; and, in addition, the same
girl who starred in a four page spread—standing in a
debris lot with boy-friend, playing hide-and-seek with
boy-friend, and mouthing it with boy-friend. Through
hard work, we suppose, she worked her way up to a
full page solo appearance in 1968. Perhaps next year,
we will be treated to an in-depth microscopic study of
the cellular structure of this dynamic duo.
The ingenuity of 1968's staff does not end here,
however. We are also treated to an entire book of Elia
Katz, a figure well-known to "with it" Hopkins literati.
Hopkins literati will also discover that the Katz booklet
is the twentieth variation on his "Buster" stories which
he has been peddling around Baltimore since his arrival.
At this point, speaking of Katz, we should mention
the season for producing a soft cover yearbook. For
financial reasons, the soft-covered edition was necessary in
order to accommodate the Katz edition.
In addition to these disturbing complaints, the
selection of photographs were poor, the group shots
(especially of sports teams) were wooden and sloppy,
and the book's composition itself was medicore. The use
of photo offset for printing was also a poor decision,
as one might note from scattered crooked lines of
copy.
Gary Nothstein, chairman of SAC which controls funds
for student activities, has frozen the Hullaballoo 's money.
This is a cause for concern.
We can understand what the Hullaballoo staff has
been trying to do with the yearbook in recent years
as evidenced by the 1967 edition. We also can
understand the actions of SAC in freezing Hullaballoo
funds. The current yearbook not only fails as "art",
but it has also failed to provide the students with an
acceptable product. Undoubtedly, the Hullaballoo has
disappointed those graduated seniors who wished to have
a record of their years at Hopkins.
However, we do hope that those who are now
investigating the status of the yearbook will understand
the necessity for ensuring that the Hullaballoo as a
publication, will continue to operate with editorial
independence in the future. Heavy-handed actions which
would convert the Hullaballoo to a high school level
publication would be regrettable.
It is imperative that the present staff of the
Hullaballoo and the committee now evaluating its
performance reach an agreement which will preserve the
editorial integrity of the yearbook and yet guarantee a
more responsible operation in relation to the students
they serve.
However, two facts should be kept in mind when
judging the Hullaballoo. First, student involvement in the
actual production of the book has been minimal in past
years. The yearbook is virtually put together by a
handful of students. Second, most of the work is done
during summer vacation when few students are willing or,
able to spend the time working on the book.
The latter problem can be remedied by the
Hullaballoo staff, itself, by juggling their deadline dates.
The former, however, depends completely on whether
Hopkins undergraduates really give a damn whether they
have a yearbook or not.

Dr. Gordon's Speech
Dr. Gordon's speech on the opening day of the
Eisenhower Symposium contained a striking touch of
irony. The Baltimore Sun applauded Dr. Gordon for,
"counseling against United States' intervention in Latin
American political affairs."
It was Dr. Gordon, as Ambassador to Brazil, who, a
scant three weeks after the military ouster of Joao
Goulart, announced his support of the forces who
overthrew a democratically elected president.
It was Dr. Gordon, in 1966, who, as Assistant
Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, told Alliance for
Progress members that the U.S. was putting "buy
American" strings on its aid. Why? According to Dr.
Gordon, the reason for such strings was to help rectify
balan,:e1 of payments deficits incurred by the "struggle
for freedom in Vietnam." Thus, reasoned Dr. Gordon,
the practice of "tied aid" was necessary.

IFilthy Corner Theatre I
By BILL MARGRABE
Although most people familiar
with the Corner Theater
Experimental Theater Club since
its inception over nine months
ago would agree that it is quite
pregnant with new ideas, there
has been an obvious failure of the
normally arty and compassionate
people of Baltimore to come to
her aid during this crucial time;
those derelict include the Hopkins
community. Les Irons, director,
has been especially concerned
with the number of people who
have joined, attended one
production, praised the
performance, then disappeared
from the experimental theater's
scene. "Attendance is our life
blood," he says.
CT'ETC, which opened in
February of 1968, is exactly what
its full name implies. The Corner
Theater bit reminds us that it is in
a sense a reincarnation of Corner
Theater Projects, which was a
1967 effort at giving Baltimore a
taste of the good thing NYC had
in Cafe' La Mama, founded there
by Ellen Stewart. Plays produced
by Corner Theater Projects
include The Burial by C. Richard
Gillespie, head of the drama
department at Towson State, and
John Osborne's Look Back in
Anger. It is a cafe' because drinks
(coffee, tea, and cocoa) are
available on the house, and
because conversation is easy to
come by before, between, and
after the plays.
Up Tight
One quote might be enough to
convince you that this is
experimental theater. According
to the Baltimore Sun a college girl
remarked that it was strange "to
have a man and woman making

love on top of her" during one of,
the plays. Of note is the apparent
demolition of the cliche' "three's
a crowd" during that show; the
girl said iit was "one of the most
exciting things that ever happened
to me." Also consonant with the.
"experimental" claim are the
Club's twin goals of offering
experimental drama to the public
and encouraging local playwrights
by producing their plays, as
production of The Burial
indicates.
.
Why a club? Because at this
time it is impractical to maintain
official "theater" status, which
would involve following the union
wage scale and fringe benefit
dictates, a theater tax, moving the
theater because of zoning lawas
from its current rent-free location
across from a hospital in the
800-block of North Howard
Street, and possible complications
resulting from objections to
sexual and scatalogical jargon.
The Club favors "using them so
freely that they'll cease to stand
out," says the Sun.
No doubt you are anxious to
hear more about CT'ETC, and
how you may become a part of
the groovy scene. CTETC is at
853 North Howard Street; its
shows run two weeks at a time
from Thursday night through
Monday night, starting always at
9 p.m. Membership for life is-five
dollars. Now playing are, The
abilsess of ladj
, Bright and At
Last We Are Alone Together, the
latter a "camp comedy" and the
fornier a "surrealistic" play from
the theatre of homosexuality.
Very Gay Blade
"Lady Bright" is a fat male
homo who goes mad before your
very eyes, unfolding the causes in

the process. "She" starts the play
trying to find somebody to share
the evening with, but nobody
seems to be around. They are all
out playing with someone else
and the "Lady" is forgotten. The
only voices she can depend on
answering "her" are dial-a-prayer,
the voices within her mind, and
the commercial ones: the airlines,
the time, weather, etc.
The Lady returns to the past,
letting the signatures of her many
callers, now preserved on her wall,
crayon symbols of the good old
days, guide her thoughts. There
was Adam, whom she had always
wanted, but never got, and
Michael Delaney, who convinced
her that the Irish could be "very
good," too. But those days were
gone. Lady Bright is old, worn
out, unwanted, alone, lonely, and
does not see any escape from this
debilitating state.
One may conclude from this
something about homosexuality:
Lady Bright was simply a fag who
was not getting her required
amount of social-sexual
relationships, Hence the crackup.
More generally the play's theme is
human loneliness; and, although
the theme is tired, the
presentation impresses one with
its novelty. Indeed, many people
may find it shocking.
There is an enthusiastic group
of Club members who feel that
experimental theater, now
overdue for acceptance should
not disappear. Indeed, it would be
a miscarriage of divine justice if
this attempt to bring a little bit of
life to Baltimore were abortive.
So, by all means see "Lady
Bright" and start an affair that
could be of immense benefit to
you and to Baltimore.

Who The Hell Is William Sulzer?
By ED MENDELSOHN
Standard studies of the
Progressive period indicate that
the officeholders of the time held
unusually high ideals. Richard
Hofstadter, for instance, states
that leadership was divided among
Wilson, Roosevelt, Bryan and
LaFollette, One may disagree
with these men, but they were
unquestionably ethical and
sincerely devoted to democratic
theory. However, they represent
only the apogee of Progressive
leadership. That there was a
perigee may be demonstrated by
the career of William Sulzer.
Sulzer was born in 1863 to
immigrant parents; as he put it,
The plain people know me." At
the age of 26 he was elected to
the New York State Assembly,
Where he became Democratic
leader in three years and advanced
to Speaker after the Democrats
won control in 1892. In 1894 he
won a previously Republican
House seat in New York City.
This could not be attributed to a
Democratic tide, since Sulzer's
party had 19 New York House
seats entering 1894 and could
only elect five. Sulzer was
continuously elected through
1910, acquiring more seniority
than any other Northern
Democractic Representative, and
when the Democrats finally won
control of Congress in 1910
Sulzer became Chairman of the
pretigious Foreign Affairs
Committee.
Weighty Career
Sulzer's legislative career is
notable for the sheer volume of
his proposed legislation, a little of
Which actually passed. Sometimes
he seemed to be merely catering
to the ethnic groups in his
district, as when he proposed to
make Columbus Day a national
holiday, to erect statues in
Washington to Generals de Kalb
and von Steuben, and to adopt a
resolution deploring Russian
treatment of Jews. Occasionally
he was astonishingly prescient, as
when he proposed a Cabinet-level
Department of Transportation, a
project which was consummated
about half a century later.
In 1912, Sulzer received what
he had long angled for, the
Democratic nomination for

Heart Transplant Performed at Hopkins Hospital
By SANDRA R. HAMMER
A team of surgical
Personnel led by Dr.
Vincent Gott and Dr.
Harvey Bender performed the
first heart transplant at the
Johns Hopkins Medical
Institutions on November 25,
1968.
Mr. Sydney Seidenberg, a
56 year old real estate
dealer from Baltimore,
received the heart of a 26
Year old victim of
irreversible brain damage, Mr.
Wilson Lieske of Havre de
Grace, Md.
Mr. Seidenberg has
experienced a progressive and
satisfactory recovery from
the operation. His vital signs
have remained within normal
limits, and he is reported
to be doing very well.
Standard Technique
The operation was
performed using the standard
open-heart technique
developed at Hopkins. Dr.
Bender removed the
recipient's heart while Mr.
Seidenberg was being
maintained on the
cardio-pulmonary by-pass
apparatus, and Dr. Gott
removed the donor's heart.
Both physicians then
installed the new heart into
Mr. Seidenberg.
The entire surgical
procedure lasted six hours.
The major concern now
entails the prevention of
infection and rejection of
the new organ.
Having undertaken two
heart operations previous to
this admission, Mr.
Seidenberg understood that
his "only hope was to get
a new heart muscle." The
recipient came to JHH one
day prior to the operation
for evaluation of a
myocardial (heart muscle)
disorder. Upon examination,
his heart appeared to be
enlarged and functioning
poorly.
"Days or Weeks"
His life at the time of
surgery could be measured
only "in days or perhaps

The Dark Ages

It is entirely possible
That is how History will refer to our time...
When the smog hovering over our cities
The dark hunger haunting our tenements
The darker crime stalking our streets
Is remembered.
However History describes our era
We hope it will also
be remembered
As the time when a young girl's heart
Beat a moment of life into a dying man .
As the time when primitive peoples
Leaped across centuries of progress
To take their place at
The World conference table..
As the time when Man first struggled to
Close the gap between the
Social and technological sciences.
You don't start clean.
Your Century is partially written.
If your chapter is to carry the torch
That can blaze across the dark corners of our age
You face a job of heroic proportions.
We think you're up to it.
You are our life insurance.

By RICH HOLLANDER
Sports Editor
I wish that the varsity basketball schedule-maker would
consult the News-Letter before he does his thing. To
appreciate my predicament, realize that the varsity
opened against Lebanon Valley last night and this
preview was scratched out two days before that. It's
something like the theatre critic who is reviewing a
play he hasn't seen but everyone else has.
Nevertheless, the roster didn't change last night and
that's the source of the hoopsters' weakness and coach
Henry Ciccarone's challenge. Even for a team that grew
up in the vitamin generation they're too small.
Excepting Bill Pietrowski and Geoff Thomas, the squad
hovers a r ou n d six feet. The natural and essential
compensation is speed and defense. Plans call for
constant defensive pressure in the hope of causing
turnovers, and keeping opponents from second and third
shots. With the ball, you'll see an exciting display of
th6 classic "run and gun" offense.
"WHO'S WHO IN BASKETBALL"
Senior co-captain Hal Thorne is one of the four
returning lettermen. He'll quarterback both the offense
and defense, calling all the plays. Although only 5 ft.
6 in., he's deadly from short range. Brain Berke is the
other senior co-captain and will engineer the running
game. Needless to say, anyone who has grown up on
Brooklyn B. Ball, like Brian, knows the game. At 6 ft.
5 in., Geoff Thomas is the Jay's board strength.
Despite the rebounding responsibilities, Thomas will
average in double figures. If the chemistry department
can come up with an aggressive pill for Bill Pietrowski,
the 6 ft. 7 in. junior can make the Jay's big winners.
PRESENT OR FUTURE?
As coach Ciccarone puts it, "Depending how fast the
sophomores mature into the varsity system, the more
games we're going to win." Last year's leading frosh
scorer, Dave Rebovich, who averaged 14.4, will hold
down the third guard slot. Joes Loveland is a complete
ballplayer, yet he specializes in pilfering basketballs.
Count on Loveland in the clutch. Should the age of
being a senior reach Thorne, he'll be backed up by
Sam Katz. Combining with Rebovich at guard last year,
Sam was consistently in double figure range.
If you want to sound like an expert, tell your date
that the varsity is working off a 1-4 offense. When
they don't set up, you'll see the organized chaos of
free lance offense. Simply, it's characterized by the
guards on the inside acting like pivot men. The defense
is less predictable. Try cliches like "full court
man-to-man" or "full court zone-press". She'll never
know the difference.
STAR ATTRACTIONS
In the course of the seventeen game season, the
Jay's will face (unfortunately) many outstanding palyers
and teams. Foremost will be Hopkins' nemesis
Muhlenberg. The Mules have everyone back from last
year's tournament team. They're sporting center Bob
McClure, who marked for 305 points as a freshman
playing varsity last season. As usual PMC and Drexel
will be tough. The sleeper of the league will be
Washington College. After a year's absence, forward Bob
Koepke, will return to the hardwoods. He was the
leading scorer on the University of Maryland freshman
team a couple of years ago,

Two Teams Gain Glory
As Fall Season Ends
By RICH HOLLANDER
Champagne all around!
Take that literally and
figuratively. There's a fiesta
on December 16 to honor
the victorious football and
soccer teams. The Jay
gri dm e n repeated for the
second straight year a:
champs of the Middle
Atlantic Conference's
Northern Division. In the
same league the soccer team
finished third out of 17
schools—their best mark since
1953.
It's the exceptional college
team that can be big
winners in successive
campaigns. Generally coaches.
build for one championship
at a time. Alex Sotir is
an exceptional coach. Using
the nucleus from last year
he molded the sophomores
and brought to Homewood
a superlative 7-2-0 record.
SATURDAY HEROES
On the Saturday before
Thanksgiving, the Jays lashed
into hapless Western
Maryland 46 to 23. This
was the icing of the

traditional rivalry, which saw
both the soccer and
cross-country teams devastate
the Terrors.
From the opening
squeaker with Muhlenberg to
the wasting of Western
Maryland the Jays scored'
306 points to 185 for
their opponents. Statistics are
the mark of a winner.
Offensives are built
around backfields and the
'68 and '67 champs are
identical. Southpaw Jim
Feely ran the show as
quarterback. Hampered by a
shoulder injury much of the
season he didn't really get
started until the closing
weeks. Neverhteless, he threw
95 completions for 1425
yards and 18 touchdowns.
His most impressive
performance was against
Dickinson where he chalked
up 262 yards. Feely's
elusive scrambling and adroit
ballhandling has set an.
example for future
generations of Hopkins'
quarterbacks. Antoher injured
here was Paul Weiss. This
year, in his junior season,
Paul led the Jays in
rushing and scoring.

Smashing tackles at a 5.6
clip, he amassed 886 yards.
Especially tough around the
g o all ine, Weiss found the
end zone 14 times. Fullback
Mark Croft provided blocking
muscle and mostly to the
inside. Rarely downed on
solo tackles, Croft drilled
the goal line on 8
occasions. Wingback Joe
Cowan has received more
copy in this paper than
Lincoln Gordon. Cowan does
most of everything and a
little bit more. One of the
most electrifying players ever
to try on a Hopkins'
jersey, Joe caught 30 Feely
passes for 651 yards and 7
scores. Color Joe great and
give him 5 more
touchdowns on the ground.

SENIORS
With the championship
comes the tragic prospect of
losing 12 seniors. Co-captains
Willie Scroggs and Don
Yablonowitz did outstanding
jobs as leaders and are
superlative athletes. Aside
from Croft, Feely and
Cowan the Western Maryland
game signalled the careers'
end for Larry Daniels, Whit
Holden, Dave Komocki, Bill
Nersesian, Gay Pasternak,
John Peck and Phil
Schro del. These men can
credit themselves with two
championships, an
achievement few varsity
college players can boast.

only has he been a
spectacular secondary
defenseman for the varsity
gridmen, but he made
valuable contributions as an
offensive back. Head Coach
Alex Sotir has been so
impressed by Coker's
versatility that, early in the
season, he offered him a
crack at the back-up slot

S.C.to Recruit
JHU Students
As Speakers
The Speaker's Bureau, a
new committee established
by the Student Council
several weeks ago, has
announced its plan to
recruit Hopkins students to
speak to various civic and
social groups in the
Baltimore area.
Mart in Hickey, chairman
of the Bu reau, said that
membership was open to all
registered undergraduates and
that every studetn would
receive an application form
in his in
this Monday
or Tuesday. Hickey said
that he has also sent
letters to a large number
of groups in Baltimore and
Baltimore County advising
them of the availability of
student speakers.
Students can choose from
a wide range of topics
includinv, questions in the
political spectrum from the
far left to the far right,
problems of the general gap
and student views of social
problems.
.
The Bureau hopes to be
sending out speakers before
Ch rist mas. Undergraduates
who want more information
should contact Martin

Garner or drop a note in
Box 179 in the Gilman
post office.

HOMEWOOD,BALTIMORE, DEC. 6, 1968

NEWS-LETTER

SA Offers Draft Program and Tom Jones
There will be three
showings on Saturday,
December 7th, at 4, 7:30
and 10 pm. and a final
showing on Sunday at 4
pm. All the showings will
be in the Great Hall of
Levering. Admission is $1.25
for the common people and
$.75 for card-carrying SA
members.

As soon as the draft
counseling program ends, the
SA will begin the first of
four showings of the
award -winning film, Tom
Jones. The movie is directed
by Tony Richardson and
features Albert Finney,
Susannah York and Joan
Greenwood.

The Student Association'
will keep Levering Hall's.
facilities in almost continual
use this weekend with a
special program on draft
counseling and two social
events.
The draft counselor
training program, sponsored'
by Dr. Wickwire, will begin;
at 9:30 am. this Saturday
morning, December 7th, and
run until 3:30 pm. The
speaker for the day will be
Mr. Arlo Tatum, Director of
the Central Committee for
Conscientious Objectors.
Participants in thei
program will have an
opportunity to examine the
Selective Service regulations
in depth in terms of their
effect on both graduate and
undergraduate students.
Anyone who wishes to
attend the session should
come to the SA office
today or call HO 7-3300,
ext. 624 or 403.

Mixed Media Hits Levering
Dr. Wickwire will take
another step into the
unknown with his innovative
Sunday Service program this
Sunday, December 8th.
Entitled "A Service in
Drama, Mime and Media"
this Sunday's program will
feature a mixed mcdia
production of Paul Claudel's
drame, Tobias and Sara. Dr.
Richard Gillespie will direct
the Glen Players of Towson
State College in the
presentation which will begin
at 11 am.

Sunday evening, Dr.
Wickwire will present Dr.
Leslie Dewart, a controversial
Roman Catholic theologian,
author and Lecturer from
St. Michael's College and
the University of Toronto.
He will speak at 8 pm. in
Levering's Great Hall on the
topic "A De-Hellenized God
for the 20th Century." On
Monday afternoon, at 2
pm., he will speak on
"Contemporary Atheism and
Christian Theism."
Dr. Dewart was born in
Spain and raised in Cuba
before he went to study in
Canada. He has taught at
the U. of Detroit as well
as at several Canadian
schools.

Seniors and
Graduate Students

SC Votes Bail
Money Refund
To Protestors
In the past two weeks,
the Student Council has
made two important
decisions with regard to
student rights.
The first action was
taken on November 25th
when the Council voted to
re fund bail to those
students who were arrested
in the demonstrations in
Washington, D.C., on
Election Day. The funds
were approved for all those
who were charged with
''demonstrating without a
permit."
In an equally important
decision the Council's request
for limited representation on
the Academic Council was
granted
As a result of the
Academic Council's approval
of student representation, the
SC established a committee
on student relations. It will
serve as a subcommittee of
the Academic Council and
will have two regular
members, two undergraduates,
two graduates and two
faculty members. (See article
on Page 5.)
